<url>http://gmane.org/img/gmane-25t.png</url>     <link>http://gmane.org</link>   </image>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8695">     <title>Re: Keybind for "evaluate a multiline command"?</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8695</link>     <description><pre> [...]   &gt; So ideally, I am looking for a command to bind to shift-enter that  &gt; would run the above thing in six hits: one per library, one for the  &gt; multiline command, and one for the head(iris).  There is no such command. There is an open request on github for semantic block evaluation, which is somewhat related to this request.   &gt; If that doesn't exist, I'll use  &gt; ess-eval-region-or-function-or-paragraph-and-step, which would force  &gt; me to use more newlines in my code, but has the advantage of running  &gt; all the library commands with one hit.  Yep, this is the way to go. I also use paragraphs as evaluation and navigation blocks.    Vitalie  ______________________________________________ ESS-help&lt; at &gt;r-project.org mailing list https://stat.ethz.ch/mailman/listinfo/ess-help  </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Vitalie Spinu</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-03-12T21:27:26</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8694">     <title>Keybind for "evaluate a multiline command"?</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8694</link>     <description><pre>Hello list,  with the help of library(magrittr), my code becomes more and more  structured in multiline commands, e.g.:   library(babynames) library(dplyr) library(magrittr) library(ggplot2)  babynames %&gt;%      filter(name %&gt;% substr(1, 3) %&gt;% equals("Ste")) %&gt;%      group_by(year, sex) %&gt;%      summarize(total = sum(n)) %&gt;%      qplot(year, total, color = sex, data = ., geom = "line") %&gt;%      add(ggtitle('Names starting with "Ste"')) %&gt;%      print head(iris)   I am using shift-enter per line, thereby torturing my enter key when  running these long commands. Is there a way for ESS to recognize these 7  lines are one command and run them with only one shift-enter?  I know of ess-eval-region-or-function-or-paragraph-and-step , which  would run that whole thing in one go, but then it would also execute  subsequent commands (the "head(iris)" in above snippet) that are not  separated by a newline.  So ideally, I am looking for a command to bind to shift-enter that would  run the above thing in six hits: one per library, one for the multiline  command, and one for the head(iris).  If that doesn't exist, I'll use  ess-eval-region-or-function-or-paragraph-and-step, which would force me  to use more newlines in my code, but has the advantage of running all  the library commands with one hit.  Best wishes, Alex  ______________________________________________ ESS-help&lt; at &gt;r-project.org mailing list https://stat.ethz.ch/mailman/listinfo/ess-help  </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Alexander Engelhardt</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-03-12T08:11:08</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8693">     <title>Re: comma in Julia REPL (change-directory, etc)</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8693</link>     <description><pre>Naturally, I would like to contribute to the ESS, especially since I find Julia very nice as a programming language but don't want any other environment than Emacs, so I will be using ESS.  However, Vitalie advised that I wait with pull requests until https://github.com/emacs-ess/ESS/issues/119 is merged. Until that happens (which I hope is very soon), I am collecting bits and pieces in https://github.com/tpapp/ESS-julia-extensions , which I plan to convert into a PR once 119 is merged.  Best,  Tamas  On Sat, Mar 07 2015, Martin Maechler &lt;maechler&lt; at &gt;stat.math.ethz.ch&gt; wrote:   ______________________________________________ ESS-help&lt; at &gt;r-project.org mailing list https://stat.ethz.ch/mailman/listinfo/ess-help </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Tamas Papp</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-03-08T17:53:15</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8692">     <title>Re: comma in Julia REPL (change-directory, etc)</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8692</link>     <description><pre>And "of course", Tamas,  we (ESS core) will/would be happy if could make your changes available, ideally via 'git pull request', or then via a "diff" patch file.. or similar.  Best regards, Martin  On Thu, Mar 5, 2015 at 10:31 PM, Vitalie Spinu &lt;spinuvit&lt; at &gt;gmail.com&gt; wrote:  ______________________________________________ ESS-help&lt; at &gt;r-project.org mailing list https://stat.ethz.ch/mailman/listinfo/ess-help </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Martin Maechler</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-03-07T19:17:49</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8691">     <title>Re: remote R</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8691</link>     <description><pre>   &gt;&gt;&gt; Andreas Leha on Fri, 6 Mar 2015 09:27:12 +0000 wrote:   &gt; Hi,  &gt; I have two questions about connecting to a remote R session.   &gt; (1) What is the state of connecting to a remote R session running in  &gt; tmux/screen?  Still no special support for screen or tmux.   &gt; I guess this is due to my setup somewhere, but before I start  &gt; digging: Is that something that I can get rid off by changing  &gt; settings on my end? Is anyone using ess/remote/tmux/R successfully?  I have no experience. Cannot comment.    &gt; (b) large regions   &gt; The whole thing works better if I use screen instead of tmux.  But there  &gt; I have issues when submitting larger regions, where R would suddenly  &gt; complains about 'unexpected symbol' while it accepts the code when I send  &gt; in smaller chunks.   &gt; Is there a solution to that?  (Other than the work around of not sending  &gt; large regions....)  Yeh. I have noticed these years ago and have no idea of why this is happening. It's something very low level (no ESS specific) which I couldn't debug or even find a reproducible example.   &gt; (2) Different R version remote   &gt; As I understand it, the 'preferred' way to start remote R is to  Yeh. Not ideal for complex work, but what can we do.   &gt; But then, how do I start R-devel, e.g., on the remote machine?  Something along the following lines:    (defun R-dev-remote ()    (interactive)    (let ((inferior-R-program-name "R-dev"))      (R)))    Vitalie  ______________________________________________ ESS-help&lt; at &gt;r-project.org mailing list https://stat.ethz.ch/mailman/listinfo/ess-help  </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Vitalie Spinu</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-03-06T15:40:44</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8690">     <title>remote R</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8690</link>     <description><pre>Hi,  I have two questions about connecting to a remote R session.  (1) What is the state of connecting to a remote R session running in tmux/screen?  (a) control characters in tmux (due to colours?)  I tried ,---- | M-x term | ssh remotemachine | tmux | R | C-c M-x ess-remote `----  This sort of works, but leads to output like this:  ,---- | &gt; [1;40r | [1;39r | &gt; [1;40r | [1;39r | &gt; [1;40r | [0] 0:nios*                                                                                             "farm3-head1" 09:07 06-Mar-15 | [0] 0:nios*                                                                                             "farm3-head1" 09:08 06-Mar-15 | [1;39r | &gt; [1;40r | [1;39r | &gt; [1;40r1+1 | [1;39r1+1 | [1] 2 | &gt; [1;40r | [0] 0:nios*                                                                                             "farm3-head1" 09:09 06-Mar-15library("plyr") | [1;39rlibrary("plyr") | [1;40r[1;39r&gt; [1;40r `----  I guess this is due to my setup somewhere, but before I start digging: Is that something that I can get rid off by changing settings on my end? Is anyone using ess/remote/tmux/R successfully?   (b) large regions  The whole thing works better if I use screen instead of tmux.  But there I have issues when submitting larger regions, where R would suddenly complains about 'unexpected symbol' while it accepts the code when I send in smaller chunks.  Is there a solution to that?  (Other than the work around of not sending large regions....)    (2) Different R version remote  As I understand it, the 'preferred' way to start remote R is to  ,---- | open a remote file using tramp | M-x R `----  But then, how do I start R-devel, e.g., on the remote machine?  Thanks, Andreas  ______________________________________________ ESS-help&lt; at &gt;r-project.org mailing list https://stat.ethz.ch/mailman/listinfo/ess-help  </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Andreas Leha</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-03-06T09:27:12</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8689">     <title>Re: comma in Julia REPL (change-directory, etc)</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8689</link>     <description><pre>  &gt; I would like to implement them, can someone please suggest another  &gt; language used by ESS that I could use as an example? Perhaps not R,  It's called ess-smart-comma and is bound to "," in repl. You have to redefine `ess-handy-commands` for julia. That's all. Just remove vignettes and other not needed stuff from there.  Most of those functions are intended to be generic. You have to look at the code of each of them. For example ess-change-directory is defined as  \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd #3259 \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd /home/vspinu/VC/ESS/lisp/ess-inf.el \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd (defun ess-set-working-directory (path &amp;optional no-error) \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd   "Set the current working directory to PATH for both ESS \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd subprocess and Emacs buffer `default-directory'." \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd   (interactive "DChange working directory to: ") \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd   (if ess-setwd-command \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd       (let* ((remote (file-remote-p path)) \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd              (path (if remote \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd                        (tramp-sh-handle-expand-file-name path) \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd                      path)) \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd              (lpath (if remote \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd                         (with-parsed-tramp-file-name path v v-localname) \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd                       path))) \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd         (ess-eval-linewise (format ess-setwd-command lpath)) \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd         ;; use file-name-as-directory to ensure it has trailing / \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd         (setq default-directory (file-name-as-directory path))) \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd     (unless no-error \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd       (error "Not implemented for dialect %s" ess-dialect)))) \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd #3275 \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd  You can immediately see from the definition of the error that the only local variable that you need to define is `ess-setwd-command`. Put it in `julia-customize-alist` and you are done. Same for other commands.     Vitalie  ______________________________________________ ESS-help&lt; at &gt;r-project.org mailing list https://stat.ethz.ch/mailman/listinfo/ess-help </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Vitalie Spinu</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-03-05T21:31:57</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8688">     <title>Re: Different results in interactive vs batch mode</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8688</link>     <description><pre>  Hi Erin:  I don't think I have never seen anything like that.  On the bright side, it is probably not an ESS issue ;o)  Rodney    ______________________________________________ ESS-help&lt; at &gt;r-project.org mailing list https://stat.ethz.ch/mailman/listinfo/ess-help  </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Sparapani, Rodney</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-03-04T22:10:00</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8687">     <title>comma in Julia REPL (change-directory, etc)</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8687</link>     <description><pre>Pressing , in the Julia REPL brings up choices for changing the directory etc, but these appear to be unimplemented for Julia.  I would like to implement them, can someone please suggest another language used by ESS that I could use as an example? Perhaps not R, since some functionality (eg vignettes) is not present in Julia so I would need to add/remove features.  Best,  Tamas  ______________________________________________ ESS-help&lt; at &gt;r-project.org mailing list https://stat.ethz.ch/mailman/listinfo/ess-help  </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Tamas Papp</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-03-04T16:10:52</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8686">     <title>Different results in interactive vs batch mode</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8686</link>     <description><pre>Hello ESS helpers,  I have been a happy user of SAS interactive mode for the last few weeks, but have run into something really strange. I wrote some code for data management using proc sql and the data step. I got it working in interactive mode (where "working" means I see the same dataset that my coworker sees independently, using his own programming). However, when I run it in batch mode, the dataset it produces is not right. I did a little poking at it looks like the batch mode version grabs the first "slice" of the data alphabetically, sliced along one of the variables I'm using to merge the datasets, but ignores the remaining 27 slices (i.e. the rows containing other values of this variable).  I could almost understand it if the interactive mode were producing something wrong. But the fact that the batch mode is getting it wrong... that really puzzles me. It happens both when I use the menu SAS-&gt;Submit File and also when I skip emacs and just run it from the command line.  Has anyone ever seen anything like this?  Erin Jonaitis  |  Biostatistician Frontier Science &amp; Technology Research Foundation 505 South Rosa Road, Suite 100  |  Madison, WI 53719 (608) 535-8300 x2062  |  jonaitis&lt; at &gt;fstrf-wi.org  ______________________________________________ ESS-help&lt; at &gt;r-project.org mailing list https://stat.ethz.ch/mailman/listinfo/ess-help  </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Erin Jonaitis</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-03-04T16:05:46</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8685">     <title>Re: Polymode markdown indents (whitespace) lost</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8685</link>     <description><pre> Thanks. You are correct, as usual.  I confirm your guess that my config caused this. If I have no init file at all, neither markdown nor polymode cause the weird "float to the left" behavior. Am tearing down my init.el to see what is causing this.Right now, it appears an errant use of the GUI customizer is at fault.        </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Paul Johnson</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-03-03T23:30:32</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8684">     <title>Re: improving ESS/julia</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8684</link>     <description><pre> On Wed, Feb 18 2015, Vitalie Spinu &lt;spinuvit&lt; at &gt;gmail.com&gt; wrote:   I have come up with some experimental (and rather trivial) code to try the extensions I need:  https://github.com/tpapp/ESS-julia-extensions  Since I am wating for the rebase on julia-mode, I did not make this fork/PR of ESS, rather something that can be used in addition.  Because I am not an experienced Emacs programmer, your comments would be very welcome, especially on the Elisp code that uses ESS (it is very short, &lt;150 LOC in Julia and elisp altogether).  In particular, is JULIA-SEND-REGION something I can hope to integrate to ESS? If not, what should I modify about it? Code below that is just for hijacking ESS keystrokes until the whole thing is integrated.  I am planning to make a PR when the rebase happens, and from then on I hope to continue making improvements to ESS/julia.  Best,  Tamas  ______________________________________________ ESS-help&lt; at &gt;r-project.org mailing list https://stat.ethz.ch/mailman/listinfo/ess-help </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Tamas Papp</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-02-28T09:31:38</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8683">     <title>Re: Polymode markdown indents (whitespace) lost</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8683</link>     <description><pre>  &gt;&gt;&gt; Paul Johnson on Fri, 27 Feb 2015 06:46:46 -0600 wrote:   &gt; OK to discuss polymode here (apart from ESS?).  Better on polymode github issue tracker.   &gt; for nested list.  I usually insert 4 spaces manually, have also  &gt; tested 2 tabs entry method. In Emacs 24.4 with polymode installed  &gt; last week, I see problem that the indented lines float back to left  &gt; side (for no reason I can discern).  Sometimes happens repeatedly, I  &gt; type space and look back as it disappears.  I don't see this. Does this happen in plain markdown-mode?  Markdown mode has a cycling indentation and indents all list from 0. You probably have some kind of auto-indentation tweak that triggers indentation after space characters.     Vitalie  ______________________________________________ ESS-help&lt; at &gt;r-project.org mailing list https://stat.ethz.ch/mailman/listinfo/ess-help  </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Vitalie Spinu</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-02-27T19:53:57</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8682">     <title>Polymode markdown indents (whitespace) lost</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8682</link>     <description><pre>OK to discuss polymode here (apart from ESS?).  In Rmd file for slides, I see problem that lines beginning with dash are pushed to the left margin. I'm writing presentations.  I type this  - pt one     - sub one     -sub two  for nested list.  I usually insert 4 spaces manually, have also tested 2 tabs entry method. In Emacs 24.4 with polymode installed last week, I see problem that the indented lines float back to left side (for no reason I can discern).  Sometimes happens repeatedly, I type space and look back as it disappears.  Have uninstalled polymode and same does not happen, so far as I can tell.  If others don't see same, it means my init file conveniences are causing trouble again, I suppose.  pj Paul Johnson http://pj.freefaculty.org  [[alternative HTML version deleted]]  ______________________________________________ ESS-help&lt; at &gt;r-project.org mailing list https://stat.ethz.ch/mailman/listinfo/ess-help  </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Paul Johnson</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-02-27T12:46:46</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8681">     <title>Re: how to leverage ESS parsing to find current module inJulia buffer</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8681</link>     <description><pre>  &gt; So it seems I would have to parse the file somehow in Emacs. But I  &gt; notice that ESS already does some of that, since it indents  &gt; everything correctly.   You have to look at the indentation code. There is no syntactic parser in ESS. Keep in mind that that this indentation code will be removed after the rebase on official julia mode.    Vitalie  ______________________________________________ ESS-help&lt; at &gt;r-project.org mailing list https://stat.ethz.ch/mailman/listinfo/ess-help  </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Vitalie Spinu</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-02-25T09:55:28</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8680">     <title>how to leverage ESS parsing to find current module in Juliabuffer</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8680</link>     <description><pre>Hi,  I am still working on improving ESS/Julia, especially the evaluation context. The problem I am facing is finding the relevant module for evaluation --- I thought I can simply search backwards with a regexp, but submodules complicate this.  For example, if a buffer contains  --8&lt;---------------cut here---------------start-------------&gt;8--- module Parent  module Child1 f(x) = x+1 end  module Child2 g(x) = x+1                      # eval here end  end --8&lt;---------------cut here---------------end---------------&gt;8---  and the user presses C-c C-c on the line that contains  g(x) = x+1                      # eval here  then the relevant module for eval is Parent.Child2. If I naively search backwards and collect all module lines that match a regexp, I get Parent, Child1, and Child2.  So it seems I would have to parse the file somehow in Emacs. But I notice that ESS already does some of that, since it indents everything correctly. Can I somehow use that to extract a list of open (ie not terminated with an "end") module expressions up to a given position?  Thanks,  Tamas  ______________________________________________ ESS-help&lt; at &gt;r-project.org mailing list https://stat.ethz.ch/mailman/listinfo/ess-help  </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Tamas Papp</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-02-25T09:37:03</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8679">     <title>Re: Wrong type argument: numberp, t</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8679</link>     <description><pre>On Monday, February 23, 2015, Ramiro Barrantes &lt;ramiro&lt; at &gt;precisionbioassay.com&gt; wrote:   I have similar experience. Pasting is generally dangerous, often hangs session entirely, session hangs saying  'Text is readonly.' Pasting in wrong spot can cause it. Pastin formatted text can cause it. And pasting from console to R file can be fatal too.  SOLUTION. Stop pasteng into console. Use ESS as God intended. Send lines over using the keystrokes.  Or use the buttons like -&gt;.  ESS NOW has convenient shortcuts. C-RET to send lines.  Nobody should ever paste into console. Doing that means you dont understand the basic benefit of ESS. Emacs experts don't notice these things because they use proper keystrokes. I resist much of the 'memorize C-x M-q' advice, but there's no defending paste into *R*.  Honestly, I suspect deeper cut/paste problems in newer emacs. Left click selection very different.      </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Paul Johnson</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-02-24T11:47:31</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8678">     <title>Re: completion</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8678</link>     <description><pre>Hi Vitalie,  Vitalie Spinu &lt;spinuvit&lt; at &gt;gmail.com&gt; writes:  That sounds encouraging.  I am looking forward to testing the first working version.   Well, for some methods with many methods / arguments (print, plot, ...) the list is quite useless as the relevant options are not visible.  But maybe that is not too important.  Thanks, Andreas  ______________________________________________ ESS-help&lt; at &gt;r-project.org mailing list https://stat.ethz.ch/mailman/listinfo/ess-help  </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Andreas Leha</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-02-24T11:46:41</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8677">     <title>Re: completion</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8677</link>     <description><pre>  &gt; Most useful for me would be  &gt; 1. the completion in dplyrs verbs  Feasible of course. We can even piggyback on rstudioapi:)  I would especially interested in data.table within [] completion.    &gt; 2. completion of S3 / S4 methods  This has always been in ESS in the sense that all arguments from all methods are provided for completion and eldoc. I don't see the narrowed completion based on the evaluated first argument as a major advantage.     Vitalie  ______________________________________________ ESS-help&lt; at &gt;r-project.org mailing list https://stat.ethz.ch/mailman/listinfo/ess-help  </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Vitalie Spinu</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-02-24T10:53:06</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8676">     <title>completion</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8676</link>     <description><pre>Hi all,  I just read the announcement of new completion functionality in RStudio [1].  And there are a few bits that make me jealous, as I do not know how to achieve them is ESS.  Most useful for me would be 1. the completion in dplyrs verbs 2. completion of S3 / S4 methods  Is something like this already feasible without me knowing?  If not, is something similar possible in some not so distant future?  Thanks, Andreas     [1] http://blog.rstudio.org/2015/02/23/rstudio-v0-99-preview-code-completion/  ______________________________________________ ESS-help&lt; at &gt;r-project.org mailing list https://stat.ethz.ch/mailman/listinfo/ess-help  </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Andreas Leha</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-02-24T09:52:35</dc:date>   </item>   <item rdf:about="http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8675">     <title>Re: Wrong type argument: numberp, t</title>     <link>http://permalink.gmane.org/gmane.emacs.ess.general/8675</link>     <description><pre>  Whenever you get an error in Emacs, try generating a backtrace.  From the *info*: ---------------------------------------------------------------------- If Emacs reports an error, backtraces can help us debug the problem. Type "M-x set-variable RET debug-on-error RET t RET".  Then run the command that causes the error and you should see a *Backtrace* buffer containing debug information; send us that buffer.  ______________________________________________ ESS-help&lt; at &gt;r-project.org mailing list https://stat.ethz.ch/mailman/listinfo/ess-help  </pre></description>     <dc:creator>Stephen Eglen</dc:creator>     <dc:date>2015-02-23T20:23:48</dc:date>   </item>   <textinput rdf:about="http://search.gmane.org/?group=$group=gmane.emacs.ess.general">     <title>Search Engine</title>     <description>Search the mailing list at Gmane</description>     <name>query</name>     <link>http://search.gmane.org/?group=$group=gmane.emacs.ess.general</link>   </textinput> </rdf:RDF>
